titleStmt.title: A praise poem of Ur-Namma (Ur-Namma I) -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

div1.p: He is the &X;&X; of his god; all the foreign countries are full (?) of his fame. He carries out his plans, and Sumer is &X;&X; by his greatness. Utu marches before the king.

King, white me&c; tree growing in a pleasant spot in Urim, a shady canopy of numerous large branches facing the sky, years of abundance extending over all foreign countries for those who keep close (?) to your shade. An looks with favour at &X;&X;, &X;&X; with joy &X;&X;.
Ur-Namma, son of Ninsumun, king given strength by Enlil, tenderly cared for by Ninlil, enthroned by the will of Nin&h;ursa&g;a, provided with superior intelligence by Enki,
May Ninsumun, the mother who gave you birth, hold you against her chest in the E-ki&c;-nu-&g;al.
